thread.title: Abuse claims arise from New Orleans playground football; 'He said he hit him 18 times'
thread.title_full: Abuse claims arise from New Orleans playground football; 'He said he hit him 18 times' | NOLA.com

author: Robert McClendon, NOLA.com | The Times-Picayune
title: Abuse claims arise from New Orleans playground football; 'He said he hit him 18 times'
text:
A child on a New Orleans Recreation Development Commission football team was left with visible swelling on the backs of his thighs after he was paddled by his coach at St. Roch Park during a Sept. 28 practice, according to an email the boy's relative sent Friday (Oct. 2) to New Orleans City Council members, recreation officials and news media.
The message included pictures of the boy's welts, which his mother had posted on Facebook.
Two sources with knowledge of the New Orleans park system operations confirmed the St. Roch Park incident and said paddling has been reported at other parks and is a symptom of wider dysfunction well known among parents, volunteers and NORDC staff members.
NORDC has called all football coaches, who work on a volunteer basis, into a mandatory meeting Monday to discuss the abuse allegations and reassert control over the football program, the sources said.
Mayor Mitch Landrieu's office, which handles communications for the nominally independent commission, said that NORDC immediately suspended the entire coaching staff at St. Roch Park and launched an investigation into the allegations. The investigation confirmed that one of the coaches had paddled the child and was expelled from the program, the others were cleared, the office said.
"NORDC has a strict no paddling policy, and violating this policy is unacceptable. All volunteer coaches are informed of this policy at orientation and are required to sign a document providing written acknowledgment of this policy," said NORDC's chief executive, Vic Richard. "After immediately investigating the allegation, the coach's suspension was found valid and his volunteer privileges were revoked on Oct. 2."
The city said that the St. Roch case was the second reported case of paddling this year. Asked to provide documentation of any complaints against NORDC coaches, the Landrieu administration referred the request to its legal department.
The injuries to the child at St. Roch Park did not appear to be serious, but sources said they are indicative of a larger problem. They described coaches cursing at children and administering physical discipline that, while perhaps falling short of clear-cut child abuse, was obviously inappropriate and against NORDC's conduct policy for volunteers.
Parents accused one coach of going to his car to retrieve a pistol following an argument he had with them, the sources said, though it was unclear whether he actually produced the weapon. The coach remains in place.
Dionnica Reed, who said she is the cousin of the boy who was paddled at St. Roch Park, made reference in her email to the alleged gun threat and a separate paddling at Taylor Park in Hoffman Triangle.
In that instance, a coach was accused of paddling multiple players and expelled from the NORDC program. One of the sources, who regularly visits the park in an unofficial capacity, said the coach continued to show up at practices because NORDC staff did not enforce a policy requiring coaches to carry city-issued identification badges that identify sanctioned volunteers.
In still another case, a coach tackled a player on his team of 9 and 10 year olds and later berated a child on the field during a game. He was initially suspended for multiple games, but later reinstated after missing just one contest, a source said.
Another coach accused of similar behavior was suspended for three games, according to sources.
There is a general sense among coaches that enforcement of conduct violations is unfair, the sources said.
Coaches, parents, volunteers and former employees who say the park system is poorly managed and a toxic work environment have been pushing, publically and privately, for Richard's ouster.
Councilwoman LaToya Cantrell is sponsoring legislation that would restructure the commission and provide the City Council with more control over its membership. Under the current setup, the commission is largely under the mayor's control.
The Landrieu administration has remained steadfast in defense of Richard, saying criticism of his leadership stems from backlash against his efforts to professionalize the park system and impose order on what had been a laissez-faire operation.
Updated at 5:32 p.m. to include a response from NORDC and the Landrieu administration.
